title: Introduction and Research Objectives
text: Figure No. 1. A photo of Orbicella annularis taken by Cheyenne L. Goodman

title: Introduction and Research Objectives
text:
Introduction
The Caribbean is home to 10% of the global coral cover, yet over 75% of Caribbean corals are considered threatened (UNEP-WCMC et al., 2021; Burke et al., 2011). Both global and local stressors such as disease and thermal stress has caused massive die-offs in corals and other ecologically important species such as Diadema antillarum ; therefore, causing an increase in macroalgae (Jackson et al., 2014). Figure No. 1 shows a reef building stony coral, Orbicella annularis that provides shelter and structure to reef fish.
 Native to the Caribbean, there are eight species of damselfish that range from herbivore and planktivores. These fish have aggressive behavior that causes them to defend their territories and bite coral to create algal gardens for food (Kaufman, 1981).

title: Introduction and Research Objectives
text:
Research Objectives
I aim to answer these questions with my research thesis:

Does damselfish presence through predation bites and algal gardens truly negatively impact coral growth?
How does damselfish presence and algal gardens negatively impact the recovery of corals after thermal stress?
How has damselfish presence correlated to coral health, disease, and bleaching recovery within the past 10 years?

title: Introduction and Research Objectives
text:
References
Burke, L., Reytar, K., Spalding, M. & Perry, A. (2011). Reefs at risk revisited. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute (WRI).
Jackson, J., Donovan, M., Cramer, K., & Lam, V. (2014). Status and trends of Caribbean coral reefs: 1970-2012. Gland, Switzerland: Global Coral Reef Monitoring Network; International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
Kaufman, L. (1981). There was Biological Disturbance on Pleistocene Coral Reefs. Paleobiology, 7(4), 527–532.
UNEP-WCMC, WorldFish Centre, WRI, TNC (2021). Global distribution of warm-water coral reefs, compiled from multiple sources including the Millennium Coral Reef Mapping Project. Version 4.1. Includes contributions from IMaRS-USF and IRD (2005), IMaRS-USF (2005) and Spalding et al. (2001). Cambridge (UK): UN Environment World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

title: Introduction and Research Objectives
text:
Background
This website serves as a record of my progress in the Masters in Marine in Environmental Science program at the University of the Virgin Islands. This website is created for MMES 565 taught by Jeremiah Blondeau.
